meanings.definition: To remove soluble or harmful substances from a material by the action of a liquid.
meanings.sent1: The rain helped leach the salt from the soil.
meanings.sent2: Farmers use water to leach nutrients into the soil for crops.
meanings.sent3: The sponge seemed to leach up all the spilled juice.
meanings.sent4: Her kindness seemed to leach away the bitterness in his heart.
meanings.sent5: The detergent can leach out the tough stains from the fabric.

meanings.definition: To drain away from soil, ash, or similar material by the action of percolating liquid.
meanings.sent1: The heavy rain can leach nutrients from the soil.
meanings.sent2: Water can leach minerals from rocks over time.
meanings.sent3: The leaky faucet seemed to leach water into the sink all night.
meanings.sent4: His words seemed to leach the enthusiasm from the team.
meanings.sent5: The constant dripping can leach the paint off the wall.

meanings.definition: A substance that has been leached.
meanings.sent1: The leach from the coffee grounds can be used as a natural fertilizer.
meanings.sent2: The leach from the wood chips added flavor to the stew.
meanings.sent3: The leach from the tea leaves made a surprisingly good dye.
meanings.sent4: The leach from the compost bin was rich in nutrients.
meanings.sent5: The leach from the herbs gave the soup a unique taste.
